w:r.w:t: AN EDGE AI-BASED AUTOMATED SOLUTION FOR EFFICIENT WASTE MANAGEMENT

With the rapid growth of urbanization and population, waste generation has increased significantly, posing a challenge to maintaining a clean and sustainable environment. Overflowing bins in cities lead to unhygienic conditions and environmental degradation. To address this issue, we have developed the "SMART WASTE SEGREGATION BIN" to automate waste sorting into different categories, making the waste management process more efficient and less reliant on manual labour. This system is designed to categorize waste into four types: metal, plastic, glass, and biodegradable, helping streamline the recycling process and protect the health of sanitation workers. Utilizing advanced sensors, the system detects the type of waste and directs it to the appropriate bin. This solution is cost-effective and contributes to sustainable waste management by reducing human involvement and promoting recycling through efficient waste segregation.
Smart Waste Bin, edge AI, Waste Segregation, Automation, Environmental Protection.

In urban environments, traditional waste management systems largely depend on manual sorting of waste from mixed bins. This method is labor-intensive, costly, and poses health risks for workers due to their direct exposure to potentially hazardous materials within unsorted waste. While some automated solutions are available, utilizing basic sensors to classify waste into categories such as organic, recyclable, and non-recyclable, these systems often lack the advanced capabilities necessary for precise sorting. Such limitations result in the need for additional manual handling, especially when dealing with materials like metal and plastic, which restricts the scalability and efficiency of these systems for larger waste management infrastructures. Therefore, there is a strong demand for a standalone, efficient, and
user-friendly solution capable of autonomously segregating waste into primary categories, making disposal and recycling more practical and sustainable on a larger scale.

with traditional landfill-based disposal methods causing environmental and health issues like water pollution and disease risks. In India, waste recycling relies heavily on ragpickers, who face serious health hazards from direct exposure to waste.

aims to automate waste sorting at the source, categorizing it into metal, plastic, and organic types, thereby reducing the need for manual labor and minimizing health risks. This compact, cost-effective, and user-friendly solution promotes efficient recycling and sustainable waste management in urban areas.
Manual waste segregation poses health risks to the workers involved. To address these issues, we have designed an organized, automated waste segregation

system. Our proposed system is an edge AI-based Smart Waste Segregation Bin that efficiently categorizes waste into metal, plastic, organic matter and glass, aiming to keep urban environments clean and hygienic. Given the rapid population growth, maintaining a sanitary environment is essential for public health, especially in smart cities.

When waste is disposed of in the bin, a LIDAR sensor detects the incoming object, activating the Pi camera that captures an image of the item. This image is then processed by an AI model, which classifies the items as Plastic, Glass, Organic Matter, or Metal. Based on the classification, the system instructs servo motors to adjust flaps, directing the waste to the appropriate compartment. The vertical alignment of flaps and perpendicular axes of rotation is our novel innovation. This automated process ensures efficient, accurate waste segregation with minimal human intervention. Coordinated by a Raspberry Pi, the system operates in real-time,
without needing an internet connection with inference done by the model deployed on the Raspberry pi itself (edge),
making it suitable for deployment in public spaces to support sustainable waste management. By automating the sorting process,
the system reduces labor costs and minimizes direct human exposure to waste, making waste handling safer and more efficient.
5The required hardware components for the Smart Waste Segregation Bin system are as
This is the main control unit of the system. It processes the data from various sensors and the camera, determining the type of waste and controlling the sorting

Raspberry Pi 4 is a small, affordable computer capable of handling multiple tasks simultaneously. It is used here to manage sensor inputs, control motors, and perform image processing tasks. Its compact size and compatibility with various sensors and modules make it an ideal choice for embedded projects like this.

These high-torque servo motors are used to operate the flaps that direct waste into the appropriate bin based on its type. They are known for their precision and durability, making them suitable for repeated operations in the segregation process. These servo motors provide the mechanical movement required to sort waste. With a 180-degree rotation and high torque, they are perfect for controlling flaps or gates in the segregation bin, directing waste into different compartments.

This LIDAR sensor provides accurate distance measurements, which are used to detect the presence and distance of waste. It aids in ensuring that waste is positioned correctly before being sorted. The VL53L0X is a Time-of-Flight (
) LIDAR distance sensor, which measures the time it takes for a pulse of light to travel to an object and back.
The Sensor is used to check for objects falling on the platform and triggers the camera to take a photo for item classification.
The camera module captures images of the waste, allowing the Raspberry Pi to analyze the type of waste based on visual characteristics. It plays a crucial role in identifying different types of

camera module is used to capture images of the waste material. The images are then processed by the Raspberry Pi to identify the type of waste. This module is lightweight, easy to interface with the Raspberry Pi, and suitable for image-based waste classification.
The following software tools are used in the system
or implementing this automated waste segregation system, the following libraries and frameworks are used:
his combination is used to train the AI model for waste classification, leveraging GPU acceleration for efficient training of large datasets.
The trained model is exported in ONNX format for compatibility and ease of deployment. ONNX enables seamless model portability across different platforms and frameworks.
This lightweight, cross-platform library facilitates high-performance model inference using the ONNX
file, allowing the model to run efficiently on the Raspberry Pi for real-time waste classification.
This library manages GPIO pins on the Raspberry Pi, allowing for precise control of hardware components, including the servo motors responsible for directing waste into specific compartments.
This library interfaces with the VL53L0X LIDAR sensor, enabling accurate distance measurement to detect the presence of waste entering the bin and triggering the classification process.
before sending them to the AI model for classification.
The YOLO dataset is acquired from Robovision universe {1} and contains three folders, train, test, and validate each folder containing images and their corresponding confidence for the classes.
This Dataset is acquired from Kaggle and
- Early stopping based on validation accuracy
- Raspberry Pi 4 (1GB RAM) as central processing unit
- VL53L0X LIDAR sensor for object detection
- Two MG995 servo motors for waste direction control
- Raspberry Pi Camera v1.3 for image capture
- Vertical flap mechanism with two servo motors
- LIDAR sensor positioned for optimal detection
- Camera mounted for clear view of waste items
- Average inference time: 850ms on Raspberry Pi 4
- Faster inference time possible with model quantization
- Additional waste categories can be added
- Enhanced error handling for edge cases

With rapid urbanization and population growth, efficient waste management has become a pressing concern. Manual waste segregation is labor-intensive, costly, and often inconsistent. This report presents a Smart Waste Segregation Bin as a compact, affordable, and automated solution for segregating waste into metal, plastic, and organic categories. The proposed system minimizes human intervention and enhances the recycling process, promoting environmental sustainability. Designed for domestic and institutional use, the Smart Waste Segregation Bin aims to streamline waste sorting at the source, facilitating timely waste collection and disposal.

The Smart Waste Segregation Bin has been designed to sort waste into metal, plastic, and organic categories. Future enhancements could include advanced AI algorithms for more precise material identification, integration of

Internet of Things (IoT) for real-time monitoring and solar-powered energy sources to make the system more sustainable. Expanding the system's capabilities could also involve implementing self-cleaning mechanisms and larger capacity
bins to accommodate usage in public spaces and industrial settings, making it a valuable tool for large-scale waste management efforts.

- VL53L0X LIDAR: VCC -> 3.3V (Pin 1), GND -> GND (Pin 6), SDA -> GPIO2 (Pin 3), SCL -> GPIO3 (Pin 5)
- Servo 1 (Upper): Signal -> GPIO12 (Pin 32), Power -> 5V, Ground -> GND
- Servo 2 (Lower): Signal -> GPIO13 (Pin 33), Power -> 5V, Ground -> GND
- Camera: Using Raspberry Pi Camera V1.3
- Shutdown Button: Signal -> GPIO21, Ground -> GND
